title: Electric flux - changing dimensions of loop

content.description: A rectangular loop lies in the <math alttext="x y" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></math>-plane with height <math alttext="b" overflow="scroll"><mi>b</mi></math> along the <math alttext="y" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>-axis and length <math alttext="a" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math> along the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>-axis, as shown. The lower left corner of the loop is at the origin. There is an electric field in the entire region that is directed out of the page and with magnitude given by <math alttext="E equals C x squared" overflow="scroll"> <mi>E</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mi>C</mi> <msup> <mi>x</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msup> </math>, where <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mi>C</mi></math> is a constant with appropriate units.
content.question: Which of the following changes would produce the largest change in the electric flux through the loop?

choices.label: Doubling the height <math alttext="b" overflow="scroll"><mi>b</mi></math> while keeping the lower left corner at the origin
Doubling the length <math alttext="a" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math> while keeping the lower left corner at the origin
Doubling the constant <math alttext="C" overflow="scroll"><mi>C</mi></math> while keeping the lower left corner at the origin
Shifting the loop a distance <math alttext="a" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math> in the <math alttext="positive x" overflow="scroll"><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi></math>-direction

content.answer: Doubling the length <math alttext="a" overflow="scroll"><mi>a</mi></math> while keeping the lower left corner at the origin
